We learn best when we can connect ideas to each other. Connecting new learning with what you already know will make learning easier and help it stick.

Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–7, find the factored form of the quadratic expression.

  1. \(x^2+4x − 12\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x − 2)(x + 6)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−3x −18\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((x − 6)(x + 3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2− 12x − 45\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x − 15)(x + 3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−x −20\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((x − 5)(x + 4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+2x −35\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x − 5)(x + 7)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−23x −50\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((x − 25)(x + 2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+7x −60\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((x − 5)(x + 12)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Consider the expression \(x^2+bx - 80\), where the leading coefficient equals 1. Identify all the pairs of factors of –80 that would result in positive values of \(b\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 80 and –1, 40 and –2, 20 and –4, 16 and –5, 10 and -8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Consider the expression \(x^2+ bx - 80\), where the leading coefficient equals 1. Identify all the pairs of factors of –80 that would result in negative values of \(b\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is –80 and 1, –40 and 2, –20 and 4, –16 and 5, –10 and 8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Identify the missing symbols:

\(x^2\; \square \; 15x \;\square\; 34\) and \((x + 2)(x − 17)\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.7.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is − and −. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
